 Data is non-interleaved. This is applicable for ADC while operating in non-interleaved mode and for all user data. More...

 Data Format: Only ADC data is being streamed over the LVDS. More...
 
#define HSI_HEADER_FMT_CP_ADC   0x2
 Data Format: Chirp Profile + ADC data is being streamed over the LVDS. More...
 
#define HSI_HEADER_FMT_ADC_CP   0x3
 Data Format: ADC data + Chirp Profile is being streamed over the LVDS. More...

 Data Format: ADC + User Data is being streamed over the LVDS. More...
 
#define HSI_HEADER_FMT_CP_ADC_CQ_USER   0x7
 Data Format: Chirp Profile + ADC data + Chirp Quality + User Data is being streamed over the LVDS. More...
 
#define HSI_HEADER_MAX_USER_BUFFER   3U
 This is the maximum number of user buffers which can be supported in the HSI Header. This should be the same as the MAX number of user buffers supported in the CBUFF Driver. However we cannot use the same macro here because it will make the file dependent on the mmWave SDK. So instead we redefine the macro and verify the sanity during the HSI Header initialization.
 
#define HSI_HEADER_MAX_CQ   3U
 This is the maximum number of chirp quality which can be supported in the HSI Header. This should be the same as the definition supported in the ADCBUF Driver. However we cannot use the same macro here because it will make the file dependent on the mmWave SDK. So instead we redefine the macro and verify the sanity during the HSI Header initialization.
 
#define HSI_DCA_MIN_DELAY_MSEC   12U
 The DCA1000EVM FPGA needs a minimum delay of 12ms between Bit clock starts and actual LVDS Data start to lock the LVDS PLL IP. This is documented in the DCA UG.
 
#define HSI_DATA_CARD_ALIGNMENT   256U
 The HSI Header Size is the maximum size of the HSI Header. The DCA1000EVM FPGA requires the data to be aligned on 256 bytes. While creating a header applications can specify the alignment requirements.
 
#define HSI_HEADER_MAX_APP_HDR_SIZE   8U
 The HSI header allows an application to add an application defined extension header. This is the maximum size of the header.

Detailed Description

The header file exposes the HSI header and associated definitions. HSI headers are created and attached to an LVDS stream which is being transmitted. The headers can be decoded on the peer where the stream is received to get access to the actual data.

This file can be used independently and does not have any dependencies on the mmWave SDK.
